awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) exhibit exceptional mechanical, thermal, and electronic properties but are still very expensive to manufacture. The production volume of CNTs is currently growing at ~15%/year but the amount of CNTs produced today is miniscule (0.01%) compared to carbon black, a material commonly used today in many applications such as automotive tires. Because the current CNT growth processes are not cost effective, CNTs are not used in many applications despite their higher performance. This research project investigates and develops the underlying science and technology of new synthetic scalable processes to make ultralong CNTs by taking advantage of minimizing the amount of seed chemical (catalyst) required. Over 90% of carbon black in use today is for rubber reinforcement, mostly in automobile tires where the carbon provides a preferred trade-off between the rolling resistance/wet traction for improved gas mileage. Increased gas mileage of 3-5% could be achieved if CNTs were used instead of carbon black in tires, which in turn could reduce US greenhouse gas emissions by ~1%, providing significant societal and economic benefits for the US. This project is jointly funded by the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

The mechanism underlying the growth of ~1 mm long carbon nanotubes on exfoliated laminar mineral sheets, in a commercially scalable process, is investigated. The expected yield is 10-100 times higher than currently achieved and would eliminate the need to separate the catalyst/support from the nanotubes. Critical scientific and technical challenges include models for the improved catalyst dispersion within narrow lamellar catalyst layers and the reaction – diffusion conditions required so that the reactants and co-fed water can reach all active sites and extend catalyst lifetimes. The understanding and control of reactant concentration gradients is critical as it impacts the nanotube length and uniformity. Long nanotubes are unsuitable for applications that involve compounding tubes with a polymer and hence the tubes will be milled to produce lengths similar to what is commercially used today (average lengths 1-10 microns). The relationship between length reduction and ball milling parameters, specifically impact energy of a single collision and cumulative impact energy, will be determined to allow scaling up of this process to commercial milling devices. Average lengths of 10-50 microns will also be produced to better explore how longer tubes perform in compounding operations. Tubes will be mixed in one thermoplastic (polycarbonate) and one tire formulation to determine nanotube performance. CNTs of three different diameters will be milled to the same aspect ratio to determine if aspect ratio is important in filled polymer properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Long (~100 micron) multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) using a flat, ultrathin catalyst support (expanded vermiculite) were produced enabling yields (grams of CNT/grams of catalyst+support) greater than 30; micrographs of the tubes are shown in the image. To our knowledge, these are the highest yields ever reported for MWCNTs produced in an industrially scaleable process.  We were able to develop a universal scaling law based on an impact energy scaling parameter for length reduction of carbon nanotubes and applied this scaling law to these tubes to produce tubes of a given length.  The broken tubes were difficult to disperse in both a rubber and a thermoplastic (polycarbonate) which was attributed to the very ribbon like morphology of bundled nanotubes clearly evident in the middle micrograph of the attached image.   Hence, although some benefits were seen with the longer inherent lengths, the benefits were much less than what would have been found if the tubes had been dispersed at a quality equivalent to that of normal ~1 micron commercial tubes.   To be more specific, the percolation threshold, which is a good measure of dispersion, for the 50 micron tubes produced after ball milling in polycarbonate was approximately the same as for the commercial tubes.  To reduce inter-tube adhesion forces in the ribbons which should improve dispersion during mixing, we chemically modified the tubes during ball milling by adding ammonium carbonate.  As measured by the percolation threshold in polycarbonate, broken 10 micron long tubes had approximately the same percolation threshold as the as normal ~1 micron commercial tubes.   Two PhD students were supported by this project and two PhD theses will be generated because of this work. Four undergraduates worked on the project with two of these being supported by an NSF-REU supplement.    


Last Modified: 12/05/2024
Modified by: Brian P Grady

Image
  • SEM of ultrahigh aspect ratio MWCNTs prior to ball milling
    Mason Rhue
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Brian P Grady
    SEM of MWCNTs
por.por_txt_cntn:
Long (~100 micron) multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) using a flat, ultrathin catalyst support (expanded vermiculite) were produced enabling yields (grams of CNT/grams of catalyst+support) greater than 30; micrographs of the tubes are shown in the image. To our knowledge, these are the highest yields ever reported for MWCNTs produced in an industrially scaleable process. We were able to develop a universal scaling law based on an impact energy scaling parameter for length reduction of carbon nanotubes and applied this scaling law to these tubes to produce tubes of a given length. The broken tubes were difficult to disperse in both a rubber and a thermoplastic (polycarbonate) which was attributed to the very ribbon like morphology of bundled nanotubes clearly evident in the middle micrograph of the attached image. Hence, although some benefits were seen with the longer inherent lengths, the benefits were much less than what would have been found if the tubes had been dispersed at a quality equivalent to that of normal ~1 micron commercial tubes. To be more specific, the percolation threshold, which is a good measure of dispersion, for the 50 micron tubes produced after ball milling in polycarbonate was approximately the same as for the commercial tubes. To reduce inter-tube adhesion forces in the ribbons which should improve dispersion during mixing, we chemically modified the tubes during ball milling by adding ammonium carbonate. As measured by the percolation threshold in polycarbonate, broken 10 micron long tubes had approximately the same percolation threshold as the as normal ~1 micron commercial tubes. Two PhD students were supported by this project and two PhD theses will be generated because of this work. Four undergraduates worked on the project with two of these being supported by an NSF-REU supplement. 					Last Modified: 12/05/2024

					Submitted by: BrianPGrady
